newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's once mighty Conservatives seek revival.
newsitem.headline: Canada's once mighty Conservatives seek revival.

text.p: Canada's once powerful Conservative Party unveiled on Tuesday a platform of tax cuts, job creation and a balanced budget in a bid to emerge from the political doldrums in an election expected this year.
Conservative leader Jean Charest told a media briefing that he would fight the election -- which could be held as early as June -- on the key issues of jobs and taxes.
He pledged to cut income taxes by 10 percent, reduce unemployment insurance premiums by C$5 billion ($3.64 billion) and create one million jobs by the year 2005.
Charest, a 38-year-old Quebecker, was one of only two Conservatives returned to Parliament in the last election in 1993 when the Conservatives were crushed after nine years in office.

The Conservatives won 168 of 295 House of Commons seats in the 1988 election under Brian Mulroney. But years of unpopular economic policies and the failure to resolve a constitutional dispute with French-speaking Quebec eventually made Mulroney one of Canada's most reviled leaders ever.
Charest was a minister under Mulroney and Kim Campbell, Canada's first female prime minister, who served briefly as Conservative leader before leading the party to defeat.
Charest's proclaimed election platform drew quick fire from the Reform Party, the larger of Canada's two right-wing parties and from Liberal Finance Minister Paul Martin.
"It simply doesn't add up," Martin said in Ottawa.

"It's simply not possible to cut taxes by a massive amount such as they are suggesting, transfer tax points to the provinces...and at the same time balance the budget, without something giving," Martin said.
Reform leader Preston Manning questioned Charest's credibility and described the platform as "warmed-over Mulroney baloney."

"The Tories had nine years in government to deliver on their promise of jobs, balanced budgets, tax cuts and a revitalized federation," Manning told business leaders in the southern Ontario city of Oshawa.
He asserted that Reform's platform of balancing the federal budget before cutting taxes was more credible than Charest's economic program.
Reform holds all but one of its 50 seats in Western Canada, a former Conservative stronghold.
